title: Spectral set
summary: In operator theory, a set X âŠ† C {\displaystyle X\subseteq \mathbb {C} } is said to be a spectral set for a (possibly unbounded) linear operator T {\displaystyle T} on a Banach space if the spectrum of T {\displaystyle T} is in X {\displaystyle X} and von-Neumann's inequality holds for T {\displaystyle T} on X {\displaystyle X} - i.e. for all rational functions r ( x ) {\displaystyle r(x)} with no poles on X {\displaystyle X}
